instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in not powering on w/ No water damage. Found dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>... Ran power found <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> getting very hot... Replaced it short gone, Got a green light w/o fan spin... <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage was 3v. ISL had a hole burned through it so I replaced it.... No green light... Checked my soldering and even tried a new chip. I decided to measure <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> again and it was dead shorted AGAIN. Ran power, found the same mosfet getting hot... Removed it and short gone.... Stumped... What could keep causing the mosfet to burn out. Thank's Duke or Louis in advance.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message:
Replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> at the same time, aslo check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and resistance between pin 17/18 and 27/28........

Resistance between pins 27/28 should be about 3ohm
Resistance between pins 17/18 should be about 20ohm

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Current sense is OK. Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> twice

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Out of mosfets....  Ordered a bunch more... will arrive next week

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Had 2 mosfets come in for another 2879, So I replaced both <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and shorted again... Clueless

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 20093"]Replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> at the same time[/QUOTE]

If you replace ISL and do not replace mosfets, the shorted mosfet will burn the isl, now you replace mosfets but ISL is bad and will burn mosfet, this will happen endlessly...........

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Thank you... That makes sense... Mosfets will be here next week ordered a bunch.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Got the mosfets.... Replaced them and the ISL... No change... <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is good.. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still dead w/o green light.. No short to ground on PPBUSg3h or pp3v42. Replaced <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> as well with no change.... PP3V42 is present and chrgr L gate has continuity to mosfets from ISL..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: It's the SMC. Sysonewire is missing... Replaced <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>.. SMC BC ACOK is present but still nothing. This is a rabbit hole.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Still PPBUS should come on with 12.3V with a dead SMC.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] This is is really strange.... Replaced the fets... Replaced the ISL... <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is good.. Current sense is good... PPBUS is dead.. 3v42 is good... Don't know what else it could be... No shrt on PPBUS either... Maybe something to do with <SIGNAL>SMC_BC</SIGNAL> ACOK?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Sense resistor circuit. No green light either? ACOK high?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: I think I am getting trolled by a bad from the Reel ISL.... ACOK was low I believe.. I'll take another shot at in a day or so... No voltage on Chargr L Phase... It had PPBUS G3H before I replaced the fets and the ISL but it was high at 16V... So i think I just put on a dud ISL... Will update. And yes current sense is OK. No Green light..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message:
[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] OK... I have restored PPBUS. However, Still no green light.. I'm thinking bad SMC or <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>...

Adapter Sense = 1.09v
Sys One wire is jumping between .30 and .75 v
SMC BC ACOK _VCC is  0.13 v 
SMC BC ACOK is 3.21 v 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.23v So the SMC is on? 
PP3v42 is 3.42v .... 

So right now I am leaning towards a dead SMC or dead <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Forgot to add... <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.41 v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: looks more like something is bringing <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> down. i would remove <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and test for voltage at pin 1, if voltage is back to 3.4v (assuming you've already replaced the magsafe jack) then i would say smc issue try reflow if same issue replace smc.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: I just reballed the SMC... No change..  Removed <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> no change... Maybe <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> is bad?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message:
didnt want u too reball the smc. what was the voltage on pin 1 of <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> after you removed <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>? this would have told you if u have an issue on the <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> bi-directional line. this still doesnt eliminate a bad smc. Lets hope u didnt reball a bad smc.
Remove <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>, plug in and see what the voltage is at pad #1 of where <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> used to be. what is the voltage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: [USER="451"]jgraffis[/USER] I know you didn't want me to reball it, But I wanted to do it just to rule out if there was crap under it... The voltage was the same on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL>  with <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> removed ,I forgot to include that in the above post.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: So it was about .70 v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: that should rule out bad smc. some how u have a problem between <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>. i would test resistance on <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR>, and then check rresistance to ground from pad 1 on <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> to pin 4 of <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>. kinda sounds like the trace is bad or <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> is screwed and bringing down the voltage from <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>. report back with findings please.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Made a mistake and posted from a smoothbrain moment... Delete this post..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: [USER="451"]jgraffis[/USER] ... Trace was blown... Ran a wire but still no green light... But we have 3.41 V now

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Onewire and adapter sense are both at 3.40v now but no green light

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: I've had a board with the same adapter sense and onewire readings before.... <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> is bad... And of course it's stolen off all my donors... More on the way thogh

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>SLC_BCACOK</SIGNAL> and 3.42 is present then you have an smc issue

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Also make sure the old trace is not shorted to ground. This is unlikely but had it happen to me. The smc should be sending signal for green light. I would replace smc next.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: I've had onewire and Adapter sense be the same 3.4 v and <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> was bad... When I was troubleshooting this board I replaced <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> from one I had on my mat... now that I think about it, that <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> that I used may have been a bad one

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: No shrt on trace

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Put old <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> back on

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: [USER="451"]jgraffis[/USER] No idea where it went lol... More are on the way

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: Mark as solved now fixed

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: well what was the fix?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> Keeps shorting to gnd
threads.message: @igraffis... The wire from <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> to <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>... Then I got trolled by a bad DC in board... Plus the ISL and <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and 35.
